# Light Design System

![Built With Stencil](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Built%20With%20Stencil-16161d.svg?logo=data%3Aimage%2Fsvg%2Bxml%3Bbase64%%2BCjxzdHlsZSB0eXBlPSJ0ZXh0L2NzcyI%2BCgkuc3Qwe2ZpbGw6I0ZGRkZGRjt9Cjwvc3R5bGU%%2BCg%3D%3D&colorA=16161d&style=flat-square)
[![Commitizen friendly](https://img.shields.io/badge/commitizen-friendly-brightgreen.svg)](http://commitizen.github.io/cz-cli/)
[![Storybook](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/storybookjs/brand/badge/badge-storybook.svg)](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook)

A light and non-opinionated design system build with [StencilJS](https://stenciljs.com/).

## Browser support

Currently the following browsers are supported:

- Google Chrome version 76 and above
- Safari 11.0 and above
- Firefox 68 and above
- Edge 17 and above
- Mobile Safari iOS 6 and above

> Service is not guaranteed on Internet Explorer.

## Stencil

Stencil is a compiler for building fast web apps using Web Components.

Stencil combines the best concepts of the most popular frontend frameworks into a compile-time rather than run-time tool.  Stencil takes TypeScript, JSX, a tiny virtual DOM layer, efficient one-way data binding, an asynchronous rendering pipeline (similar to React Fiber), and lazy-loading out of the box, and generates 100% standards-based Web Components that run in any browser supporting the Custom Elements v1 spec.

Stencil components are just Web Components, so they work in any major framework or with no framework at all.

## Storybook

[Storybook](https://storybook.js.org/) is an open source tool for building UI components and pages in isolation. It streamlines UI development, testing, and documentation.

## Getting Started

To start building components, clone this repoy:

```bash
git clone git@github.com:TheodoreGC/light-design-system.git
cd light-design-system
```

and run in a terminal:

```bash
npm install
npm build.watch
```

Then, in another terminal, run:

```bash
npm run storybook.prebuild # Only the first time
npm run storybook
```

To build the component for production, run:

```bash
npm run build
```

To run the unit tests for the components, run:

```bash
npm test # specs + E2E
npm test.unit # specs
npm test.e2e # E2E
npm test.watch # Watch for changes in tests
npm test.write # Run tests and save the result in `.jest-test-results.json`
```
